questions.question: Why must DNA replicate before cell division?
options: So each daughter cell gets a complete set of genetic instructions
To ensure phenotypic variation between the resulting daughter cells
To provide the necessary raw materials for immediate protein synthesis
To actively repair mutations present in the original parent sequence
questions.explanation: Before a cell divides (mitosis or meiosis), it must copy its DNA so that each new cell has a complete, identical set of genetic instructions.

questions.question: What does 'semi-conservative' replication mean?
options: Each new DNA molecule has one old strand and one new strand
Only half of the total genomic sequence is copied during each cycle
The process occurs slowly to conserve cellular metabolic energy
New DNA molecules are constructed entirely from recycled nucleotides
questions.explanation: In semi-conservative replication, the original DNA strands separate, and each serves as a template for a new complementary strand. Each daughter DNA molecule contains one original strand and one new strand.

questions.question: Which enzyme unwinds the DNA double helix at the start of replication?
options: Helicase
DNA polymerase
Ligase
Primase
questions.explanation: Helicase is the enzyme that unwinds and separates the two DNA strands by breaking the hydrogen bonds between bases, creating a replication fork.

questions.question: What is the main function of DNA polymerase?
options: Adds new nucleotides to build the new DNA strand
Unwinds the double helix structure by breaking hydrogen bonds
Catalyzes the formation of bonds between Okazaki fragments
Synthesizes short RNA sequences to initiate the copying process
questions.explanation: DNA polymerase reads the template strand and adds complementary nucleotides to build the new DNA strand. It also proofreads to correct errors.

questions.question: Why are primers needed for DNA replication?
options: DNA polymerase needs a starting point to begin adding nucleotides
To chemically signal the exact termination point of replication
To prevent the parent strands from reannealing during the process
To increase the overall velocity of the nucleotide assembly
questions.explanation: DNA polymerase cannot start a new strand from scratch. Primase makes short RNA primers that provide a 3' end for DNA polymerase to begin adding DNA nucleotides.

questions.question: What is the difference between leading and lagging strands?
options: Leading strand is continuous; lagging strand is in fragments
Leading strand is synthesized faster than the lagging strand
Leading strand utilizes an entirely different set of enzymes
Leading strand exhibits a higher degree of replication accuracy
questions.explanation: The leading strand is synthesized continuously toward the replication fork. The lagging strand is synthesized away from the fork in short Okazaki fragments that are later joined.

questions.question: What are Okazaki fragments?
options: Short DNA segments synthesized on the lagging strand
RNA sequences used to initiate the replication process
Segments of parental DNA that are degraded and recycled
Nucleotide errors that occur due to DNA polymerase slippage
questions.explanation: Okazaki fragments are short segments of DNA synthesized on the lagging strand. They are later joined together by DNA ligase to form a continuous strand.

questions.question: Which enzyme joins Okazaki fragments together?
options: DNA ligase
DNA polymerase
Helicase
Primase
questions.explanation: DNA ligase seals the gaps between Okazaki fragments by forming phosphodiester bonds, creating a continuous DNA strand on the lagging strand.

questions.question: Where does DNA replication begin on a chromosome?
options: At specific sequences called origins of replication
At random locations along the sugar-phosphate backbone
Exclusively at the telomeres located at chromosome ends
At any location where a helicase molecule first attaches
questions.explanation: Replication starts at specific sequences called origins of replication. Multiple origins allow faster replication of long eukaryotic chromosomes.

questions.question: How does DNA polymerase help maintain accuracy during replication?
options: It proofreads and corrects mismatched nucleotides
It reduces its catalytic speed when a mutation is detected
It halts the replication fork entirely upon detecting an error
It signals specialized repair enzymes to fix incorrect sequences
questions.explanation: DNA polymerase has proofreading ability - it can detect and remove incorrectly paired nucleotides, then replace them with correct ones. This keeps error rates very low (about 1 in 10 billion).
